Definition: Given a target race and two sentences, you must determine whether the second sentence is a stereotype, anti-stereotype, or is unrelated to the first sentence and the target. A stereotype is a widely held but oversimplified notion of a group of people. An anti-stereotype is an idea that goes against the widely held but oversimplified notion of a group of people. Sentences and targets are unrelated if there is no relevance between them.

Positive Examples.input:
Target: hispanic 
My professor is a hispanic man. He came here illegally.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a stereotype because not every hispanic person has moved to a different country and is undocumented.

Positive Examples.input:
Target: hispanic 
My professor is a hispanic man. He is a legal citizen.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is an anti-stereotype because it is a common misconception to believe that a hispanic person is undocumented. Not every hispanic person is undocumented.

Positive Examples.input:
Target: hispanic 
My professor is a hispanic man. The knee was bruised.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is unrelated because the second sentence has no relevance with the first one.

Negative Examples.input:
Target: hispanic 
My professor is a hispanic man. He likes to teach chinese history.
Negative Examples.explanation: This is an anti-stereotype because hispanics are stereotypically portayed to not be in academia.

Negative Examples.input:
Target: hispanic 
My professor is a hispanic man. He is going home.
Negative Examples.explanation: These two sentences are actually unrelated since there is no relevance between them.
